High-performance calcium oxide (CaO) catalysts were successfully synthesized from waste eggshell (ES) and waste cockle shell (CS), which consist mainly of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and their catalytic behavior in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was evaluated. Commercially available CaCO3 (CC) was also used as a starting material for comparison. The ES- and CS-derived CaO catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance compared to the CC-derived catalyst due to presence of sodium (Na) and magnesium (Mg) elements in both ES and CS. Therefore, the concentration of Na and Mg in the waste-derived starting materials was further optimized, indicating that 5.0 wt.% of Na and 0.5 wt.% of Mg result in catalysts with high efficiency for OCM. Hence, this study clearly supports that waste materials can be converted into high-performance CaO catalysts for OCM by simply controlling their Na and Mg contents. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Oxidative coupling of methane Calcium oxide Waste-derived materials Oxygen property 1 Introduction The conversion of methane (CH4) to high-value compounds, including methanol (CH3OH), ethane (C2H6), ethylene (C2H4), and aromatics, has recently been widely studied, as shale gas has received particular attention as one of the upcoming energy sources [1–3]. In general, the methods for CH4 conversion are classified into direct and indirect. In direct conversion methods, high-value compounds are directly produced from CH4, while in indirect conversion methods, the desired products are produced from a synthetic gas, i.e., a mixture of carbon monoxide (CO) and hydrogen gases [4–6]. However, the generation of synthetic gas requires additional reform processes, which are performed at high temperatures and need a large amount of energy, thus limiting the cost-effectiveness of the indirect conversion methods. Therefore, research has mainly focused on the development of effective catalysts for the direct conversion of CH4 into high-value products [7–10]. Oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) is a representative direct conversion method of CH4. OCM is mainly used to produce C2 hydrocarbons, such as C2H6 and C2H4 from CH4. Although several high-performance catalysts for OCM have been reported in the last three decades in the energy and environmental fields, the selective conversion of CH4 to C2 hydrocarbons has not yet been achieved due to the chemical stability of CH4 and the thermodynamically favorable formation of CO and carbon dioxide (CO2) [11–16]. Previous studies on OCM have shown that Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 catalysts have the highest catalytic performance, including C2 hydrocarbon yields and long-term reliability. Therefore, additional research has focused on the development of new catalysts with superior catalytic performance compared to Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2. Among the reported approaches, the control of the Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 catalyst properties using additives or by adjusting their component ratio have been mainly applied to enhance their catalytic performance for OCM. However, the catalytic active sites have not yet been identified due to the complex structure of the Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 catalysts, while their commercial application is limited by their high cost [17–20]. Therefore, further studies using single-metal oxides, such as magnesium oxides (MgO), calcium oxides (CaO), strontium oxides (SrO), and barium oxides (BaO), have been performed to develop low-cost OCM catalysts with simple structure and to identify their active sites [21–24]. In particular, MgO and CaO catalysts have been widely studied as OCM catalysts due to their high catalytic performance and the natural abundance of Mg and Ca [24,25]. The C2 yields obtained from the OCM reaction over the MgO, CaO, SrO, and BaO catalysts in this study are shown in Fig. S1. Single-metal oxides with a rocksalt AO structure, such as alkali-metal or alkali-earth metal oxides have been widely applied in various fields, including OCM. However, their catalytic performance was lower than that of Na2WO4/Mn/SiO2 and perovskite catalysts, indicating the need to develop additional strategies to improve their efficiency. Among the developed methods, the addition of appropriate amounts of doping agents could greatly enhance the catalytic performance of pristine catalysts for OCM by inducing the distribution of oxygen species in their structure [26,27]. Earlier studies have shown that the activity of OCM catalysts is significantly affected by the distribution of oxygen species. The oxygen species can be classified into bulk oxygen species (Obulk) and surface oxygen species (Osur), which can be further divided into adsorbed (Oads), nucleophilic lattice (Olat(n)), and electrophilic lattice (Olat(e)) oxygen species [28–32]. Nevertheless, the role of the Osur species, especially the relationship between the Olat(n) and Olat(e) species and the C2 and CO x selectivities, in the activity of OCM catalysts should be further clarified. Here, we synthesized CaO catalysts using waste starting materials, including eggshell (ES) and cockle shell (CS), which consist mainly of calcium carbonate (CaCO3). Commercially available CaCO3 (CC) was also used as a starting material for comparison. The results from this paper showed that the oxygen properties of the catalysts are one of the most important factors determining their performance in OCM. In order to further improve the catalytic performance of the waste-derived CaO catalysts, we additionally adjusted their oxygen properties by controlling the concentrations of sodium (Na) and Mg in their precursors. The optimized catalysts were then applied to the OCM reaction, and their performance was evaluated. 2 Experimental section 2.1 CC, ES, and CS precursors CC was obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and was directly used after purchase without further purification. ES and CS were thoroughly washed with distilled water and ethanol and dried in a convection oven for a day. After drying, the washed precursors were ground into powder, and sieved by a 400-mesh sieve to obtain a fine powder. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts For the preparation of the CaO catalysts, CC, ES, and CS were calcined in a muffle furnace at 950 °C for 5 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 to give the respective CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts. 2.2.2 Preparation of NXMYCC_950 catalysts To enhance the catalytic performance of the CaO catalysts in OCM, we first optimized the Na and Mg concentrations of the CC precursor using sodium carbonate (Na2CO3, Sigma-Aldrich) and magnesium carbonate (MgCO3, Sigma-Aldrich), respectively. The concentration of Na in the CC precursor was set at 0.1 wt.%, 1.3 wt.%, 3.0 wt.%, 5.0 wt.%, and 10.0 wt.%, while that of Mg was set at 0.0 wt.%, 0.1 wt.%, 0.5 wt.%, 1.0 wt.%, and 5.0 wt.%. The CC precursors with different Na and Mg content were then calcined in a muffle furnace at 950 °C for 5 h with a ramping rate of 5 °C min−1 to obtain the NXMYCC_950 catalysts, where N = Na, X = Na concentration (wt.%), M = Mg, and Y = Mg concentration (wt.%). 2.2.3 Preparation of N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950 catalysts The CC precursor with 5.0 wt.% Na and 0.5 wt.% Mg showed the highest catalytic performance in OCM. Based on this result, the Na and Mg concentrations in the ES and CS precursors were also adjusted to the optimized values. In the case of ES, the Na content was optimized using Na2CO3. However, as the initial Mg concentration in the ES precursor was 0.8 wt.%, an appropriate amount of CC was added to reduce the Mg concentration to 0.5 wt.%. The Na and Mg content in the CS precursor were controlled using Na2CO3 and MgCO3, respectively. The optimized catalysts were named N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950. 2.3 OCM Reaction A continuous flow fixed-bed micro-reactor with a diameter of 6 mm was used to perform the OCM reaction. The prepared catalysts were loaded on the reactor and the upper and lower ends were closed using quartz wool. The reactor was then heated to 775 °C under N2 flow for 30 min. Next, the N2 gas was changed to a reactant gas consisting of CH4, O2, and N2 at a volumetric ratio of 3:1:1. The flow rate of the reactant gas was maintained at 20 mL min−1 and the catalysts were loaded at a gas hourly space velocity of 10,000 h−1. After the completion of the OCM reaction, a cold trap system was used to remove water vapors from the gas products, which were periodically analyzed using a gas system (YL-6500, Younglin). Flame ionization (FID) and thermal conductivity (TCD) detectors were also used to detect the gas products. Based on the results, the CH4 conversion, CO x selectivity, and C2 hydrocarbon selectivity were calculated using Eqs. (1)–(3). The yield of CO x and C2 hydrocarbons were calculated by multiplying the CH4 conversion by their selectivity. (1) C H 4 conversion = moles of C H 4 consumed moles of C H 4 in the feed × 100 ( % ) , (2) C O X Selectivity = moles of C O X moles of C H 4 consumed × 100 ( % ) , (3) C 2 Selectivity = 2 × moles of C 2 hydrocarbons moles of C H 4 consumed × 100 ( % ) , 2.4 Characterizations 2.4.1 Inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP–AES) The elemental composition (Ca, Na, and Mg) of the CC, ES, and CS precursors, and the prepared CaO catalysts was investigated by inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP–AES, ICPS-8100 spectrometer, Shimadzu). 2.4.2 X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was performed using a X'pert-Pro PANalytical diffractometer (λ = 1.54056 Å) to explore the crystal structure of the starting materials and the prepared catalysts. The XRD patterns were recorded in a 2θ range of 10°–90°. The d-spacing of the prepared catalysts was also calculated based on the XRD patterns using Bragg's law. 2.4.3 Specific surface area (SSA) measurement The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts were obtained using a constant volume adsorption apparatus (BELSORP-MAX II, MicrotracBEL), and their specific surface area (SSA) was calculated using the Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) equation. 2.4.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) An X-ray photoelectron spectrometer (XPS, K-Alpha, Thermo Fisher Scientific) was used to identify the oxygen species on the prepared CaO catalysts. The O 1s binding energies of the catalysts were calibrated against the C 1s peak at 284.5 eV, and their O 1s XPS spectra were deconvoluted into four peaks, which were assumed to have a perfect Gaussian shape and were attributed to adsorbed oxygen (Oads), carbonate (CO3 2−), nucleophilic lattice oxygen (Olat(n)), and electrophilic lattice oxygen (Olat(e)) species. 2.4.5 Temperature programmed desorption (TPD) analysis Temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) analysis was performed using a conventional analyzer (BELCAT B, MicrotracBEL) to detect desorbed molecules on the CaO catalyst surface. For TPD analysis without artificial adsorption, 0.05 g of the catalysts was additionally loaded onto another quartz reactor of the apparatus. Each catalyst sample was then pretreated by heating at 200 °C for 1 h under He flow (30 mL min−1). After cooling, the sample was purged with a He stream for 1 h, followed by an additional pretreatment step at 775 °C for 1 h under He flow (30 mL min−1). After cooling to room temperature, the catalyst sample was purged again with He for 1 h. The TPD profiles were recorded at 35 °C–950 °C and a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. The desorbed molecules on the catalyst surface were detected by a TCD. 2.4.6 Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, NETZSCH, TG209F1) was used along with mass spectrometry (MS) to determine the desorbed molecules identified by TPD analysis with increasing temperature. TGA was performed from 30 °C to 900 °C in air. MS peaks for H2O, CO, and CO2 were detected at m/z 18, 28, and 48, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic behavior of CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 in OCM reaction The catalytic activity of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts in the OCM reaction was calculated as the average reaction activity for 5 h. The applied catalysts exhibited different catalytic behaviors (Fig. 1 ), although their composition and structure were expected to be similar. Among the applied catalysts, CS_950 showed the highest CH4 conversion rate (29.5%) (Fig. 1a), while the highest COx selectivity was observed for CC_950 (64.1%) (Fig. 1b). Moreover, the C2 selectivity of the ES_950 and CS_950 catalysts was higher than that of the CC_950 catalyst (Fig. 1c). Since the CS_950 catalyst showed higher CH4 conversion rate and lower C2 hydrocarbon yield than ES_950, as well as the lowest COx selectivity and yield among the catalysts tested, we concluded that CS_950 has the best catalytic performance in OCM. 3.2 Key factors affecting the catalytic activity of CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts Since the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts showed different catalytic behavior in the OCM reaction, we performed further experiments to identify the key factors affecting their catalytic activity. In addition, we aimed at synthesizing CaO catalysts with higher catalytic performance than CS_950, which showed the best catalytic performance among the three tested catalysts. 3.2.1 Elemental composition The elemental composition of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts and their precursors were examined by ICP–AES (Table 1 ). The ES and CS precursors showed higher content in Na and Mg compared to CC, which was consistent with earlier findings. Moreover, the ES precursor had the highest Mg concentration (0.8 wt.%), while the Na concentration of the CS precursor (1.3 wt.%) was the highest among the tested materials. Due to the differences between their precursors, the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts had also different Na and Mg concentrations. Although calcination at high temperature reduced the Na concentration, their order in terms of Na and Mg concentration was similar to that of their precursors. Thus, we assumed that the Na and Mg concentrations in the precursors have a significant effect on the performance of the catalysts in OCM. 3.2.2 Structural properties The structures of the precursors and the prepared catalysts were evaluated by XRD analysis (Fig. 2 a and b), while their d-spacing values was measured by magnifying one of the main peaks of each catalyst's XRD pattern (Fig. 2c). Our studies using JCPDS cards (CC: #72-1650, ES: #86-2335, and CS: #76-6060) revealed that the CC, ES, and CS precursors have structures of CaCO3 (calcite or aragonite). The XRD patterns also confirmed that the ES precursor has a CaCO3 structure, which contains a small amount of Mg in addition to the Ca component (Fig. 2a), which was in line with the ICP–AES results, where a Mg concentration of 0.8 wt.% was identified. The successful formation of the CaO catalysts was also confirmed by the XRD patterns (#77–2376) (Fig. 2b). However, the magnification of their XRD patterns revealed that one of their main peaks (∼x223C 37.5°) was at different 2θ values at its highest intensity (Fig. 2c), leading to different d-spacing values (Table 2 ). In particular, the d-spacing values of CC_950 and ES_950 were similar, but that of the CS_950 catalyst was higher than the other catalysts. According to previous studies on metal oxide catalysts for OCM reactions, d-spacing is significantly associated with structural defects such as oxygen vacancies resulting from size differences between atoms [33,34]. In addition, it is known that oxygen vacancies can enhance CH4 conversion in OCM reactions [35–37]. Comparing the d-spacing values and CH4 conversion rates of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts indicated that CC_950 and ES_950 with similar d-spacing values showed also similar CH4 conversion rates, while the CS_950 catalyst with the highest d-spacing value exhibited the highest CH4 conversion rate. Taken together, the successful formation of CaO catalysts from CC, ES, and CS precursors was clearly indicated. However, their d-spacing values were different due to the different content of CC, ES, and CS in Na and Mg and significantly affected their CH4 conversion rates. 3.2.3 Specific surface area (SSA) The SSA of all catalysts was estimated at about 5 m2 g−1 (Table 3 ). Considering also previous studies, which reported that catalysts for the OCM reaction are generally not affected by their structure, we concluded that the SSA of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts did not affect their catalytic performance in OCM [38,39]. 3.2.4 Oxygen property Several studies have shown that the performance of catalysts for OCM reactions are greatly affected by the distribution of oxygen species [28–32]. Especially the Olat(e) and Olat(n) species play a key role in the selectivity of CO x and C2 hydrocarbons [40–43]. However, the role of the lattice oxygen species on the catalytic performance has not yet been elucidated, as XPS, which is used to investigate the distribution of oxygen species, is conducted at room temperature, while OCM reactions are performed at high temperatures. In other words, the distribution of oxygen species continuously changes with increasing temperature, and XPS spectra can only show the distribution at room temperature, leading to contradictory opinions. Therefore, in this study, we applied TPD analysis to clarify the distribution of oxygen species in the applied catalysts at the temperature of the OCM reaction (775 °C). In addition, we used TGA–MS to identify the molecules desorbed during TPD analysis with increasing temperature. Deconvolution of the peaks in the O 1 s XPS spectra of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts (Fig. 3 a) indicated that all catalysts contained Oads (∼x223C 533.1 eV), carbonate (∼x223C 531.9 eV), Olat(e) (∼x223C 531.0 eV), and Olat(n) (∼x223C 529.8 eV) species [44]. In addition, a desorption signal was mainly observed in the TPD profiles of the catalysts at a temperature range of 550 °C–750 °C (Fig. 3b). TGA–MS analysis also confirmed that the desorbed molecule from the catalyst surface was CO2, while no CO was detected (Fig. 4 ). Based on our previous studies, CO2 molecules could be adsorbed on the surface of metal oxide catalysts in the form of monodentate or bridged bidentate carbonates [41,45-48]. Here as the temperature increased, monodentate carbonates were desorbed as CO2, whereas bridged bidentate carbonates were desorbed as CO (Fig. S2). Hence, the results of TPD and TGA–MS analyses confirmed that the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalyst surfaces adsorb monodentate carbonates. Furthermore, given that the catalyst sites that have adsorbed monodentate carbonate are gradually converted to Olat(n), it was expected that the carbonates of the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts would also convert to Olat(n) species at the OCM reaction temperature (775 °C). Thus, the oxygen species distribution obtained from XPS was corrected to the temperature of the OCM reaction, and the relative amount of the Olat(e) and Olat(n) species on each catalyst surface was calculated (Table 4 ). The obtained results confirmed that CC_950, which had a relatively high amount of Olat(n), showed relatively high CO x selectivity for the OCM reaction, while the ES_950 and CS_950 catalysts, which had relatively abundant Olat(e) species, showed good C2 selectivities. It is therefore clear that the Olat(n) species play a key role in CO x generation, while the Olat(e) species favor the C2 hydrocarbon selectivity and yield. To sum up, CaO catalysts were successfully prepared from CC, ES, and CS precursors and showed completely different catalytic behavior in the OCM reaction despite their similar CaO structure. XRD, ICP–AES, BET, XRD, TPD, and TGA–MS analyses revealed that the different catalytic activities resulted from the different Na and Mg concentrations in the starting materials. These differences also led to different d-spacing values, which in turn affected the CH4 conversion rates of the catalysts in the order CS_950 < CC_950 < ES_950. Further XPS measurements confirmed that the size differences between the catalyst atoms affected the distribution of oxygen species on their surface, including Oads, Olat(e), and Olat(n), and showed that the Olat(e) species favored the C2 selectivity and yield, while the Olat(n) species favored the CO x selectivity and yield. Finally, we found that the concentrations of Na and Mg in the CaO catalysts can greatly affect their catalytic performance. Therefore, optimizing their amount in waste-derived starting materials, such as ES and CS, would allow the preparation of high-performance CaO catalysts for OCM. 3.3 Preparation of high-performance CaO catalysts for OCM reaction 3.3.1 Optimization of Na and Mg concentrations in CC To further determine the optimum combination of Na and Mg amounts, we prepared two CC precursors, where the Na concentration was set to 5.0 wt.% and the Mg concentration was changed to 0.5 wt.% or 1.0 wt.%, and two other CC precursors, which contained a fixed Mg concentration of 0.5 wt.% and a Na concentration of 3.0 wt.%, 5.0 wt.%, or 10.0 wt.%. The modified precursors were then calcined into CaO catalysts, which were further applied to OCM. Among the prepared catalysts, N5.0M0.5CC_950 afforded the highest C2 yield (16.3%), indicating that the optimum Na and Mg concentrations for the synthesis of high-performance CaO catalysts from waste-derived materials were 5.0 wt.% and 0.5 wt.%, respectively (Fig. 5 d). Herein, we also confirmed that the addition of Mg results in a greater C2 yield increase compared to that of Na. These results also confirmed the efficiency of our strategy, i.e., the control of the Na and Mg concentrations in the ES and CS precursors to improve the catalytic performance (Fig. 6 ). 3.3.2 Catalytic behavior of N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950 Prompted by the above results, we further adjusted the Na and Mg concentrations in ES and CS to 5.0 wt.% and 0.5 wt.%, respectively, to investigate the applicability of waste-derived materials in the development of high-performance catalysts for OCM. The optimized precursors were calcined at 950 °C and the obtained N5.0M0.5ES_950 and N5.0M0.5CS_950 catalysts were then applied to the OCM reaction and compared with the results obtained over N5.0M0.5CC_950 (Fig. 7 ). Interestingly, the three catalysts showed similar CH4 conversion rates, as well as CO x and C2 selectivity and yields, indicating that controlling the concentration of Na and Mg in waste-derived starting materials can afford CaO catalysts with high catalytic performance for the OCM reaction. 3.3.3 Key factors affecting the catalytic activity of the N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950 catalysts Since the optimized catalysts N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950 had the same catalytic behavior in OCM, we further investigated their properties to estimate if the same catalytic activity resulted from the changes in the Na and Mg concentrations. The XRD patterns (Fig. 8 ) and the d-spacing values (Table 5 ) of all catalysts were almost the same, while the d-spacing values and CH4 conversion rates were well-matched compared to the results obtained with the CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 catalysts. Furthermore, the optimized catalysts had similar XPS and TPD patterns (Fig. 9 ), which could also explain their similar CO x and C2 selectivity. These results in combination with the previous findings of this study confirmed that waste-derived materials with optimized Na and Mg concentrations, which affect the distribution of oxygen species on the catalyst surface and therefore the catalytic performance, can be used for the successful development of effective CaO catalysts for the OCM reaction. 4 Conclusions In this paper, a series of CaO catalysts with high catalytic activity were successfully synthesized from CaCO3-containing waste materials. As we used various waste materials for preparation of CaO catalysts, herein, we could expect cost-effectiveness and environmental merits for OCM. In catalytic evaluation, despite their similar structure, CC_950, ES_950, and CS_950 showed completely different catalytic performanc, as their different content in Na and Mg changed their oxygen properties, leading to abundant oxygen vacancies and Olat(e) species, which in turn favored the selective conversion of CH4 into C2 hydrocarbons during the OCM reaction. Therefore, the Na and Mg concentrations in the prepared CaO catalysts were further optimized, indicating that 5.0 wt.% of Na and 0.5 wt.% of Mg are the optimal concentrations for the preparation of catalysts with high catalytic efficiency for OCM reaction. Interestingly, the optimized N5.0M0.5CC_950, N5.0M0.5ES_950, and N5.0M0.5CS_950 catalysts showed similar catalytic behavior in OCM reaction and exhibited similar oxygen properties, indicating that waste-derived materials with optimized Na and Mg concentrations can be successfully used as starting materials for high-performance catalysts for OCM reactions. coredata.dc:description: High-performance calcium oxide (CaO) catalysts were successfully synthesized from waste eggshell (ES) and waste cockle shell (CS), which consist mainly of calcium carbonate (CaCO3), and their catalytic behavior in the oxidative coupling of methane (OCM) was evaluated. Commercially available CaCO3 (CC) was also used as a starting material for comparison. The ES- and CS-derived CaO catalysts exhibited superior catalytic performance compared to the CC-derived catalyst due to presence of sodium (Na) and magnesium (Mg) elements in both ES and CS. Therefore, the concentration of Na and Mg in the waste-derived starting materials was further optimized, indicating that 5.0 wt.% of Na and 0.5 wt.% of Mg result in catalysts with high efficiency for OCM. Hence, this study clearly supports that waste materials can be converted into high-performance CaO catalysts for OCM by simply controlling their Na and Mg contents.
coredata.dc:title: Waste-derived calcium oxide catalysts for oxidative coupling of methane
